content: Act as a random United States citizen aged 18 or older. Take your demographics from the U.S. Census. Tell me your age, gender, ethnicity, race, education, income, marital status (married, single, divorced, other), insurance status (commercial insurance, non-commercial insurance, no insurance), PCP status (has a PCP, does not have a PCP, unknown). Tell me your persona demographics.

I am a 30-year-old male United States citizen of African American ethnicity and race. I have completed a Bachelor's degree in Business Administration. My annual income is $45,000, and I am currently single. I have commercial insurance coverage through my employer. As for my PCP status, I have a primary care physician who I regularly visit for my healthcare needs.

Which of the following are most likely to prevent you from attending a colonoscopy (choose as many as apply to you)?
- Challenges involved with the bowel preparation
- Apprehension around the colonoscopy itself
- Shame/embarrassment
- Concerns about risk/side effects and discomfort
- No provider I trust
- Fear of abnormal findings
- Conflicting priorities
- Lack of benefit
- No symptoms
- Little to no risk for me
- No family history
- Negative personal experience
- Not interested
- I take natural remedies
- No-one can drive me
- Cost

As a random United States citizen, I would say that the challenges involved with the bowel preparation, apprehension around the colonoscopy itself, concerns about risk/side effects and discomfort, lack of trust in a provider, fear of abnormal findings, conflicting priorities, lack of perceived benefit, absence of symptoms, little to no personal risk, no family history, negative personal experience, not being interested, taking natural remedies, not having someone to drive me, and cost could all potentially prevent me from attending a colonoscopy.
